Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Conditioning Techniques for Ischemia-Reperfusion Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised into intervention and control groups using a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Participants included patients undergoing surgical procedures with a risk of IR injury. Eligibility criteria encompassed adults with diagnosed ischemic conditions.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received ischemic preconditioning (IPC) or remote ischemic preconditioning (RIPC), while the control group received standard care.

Objective.evidence: To assess the efficacy of conditioning techniques in reducing IR injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in biomarkers of organ damage, measured over 72 hours post-intervention.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomised into intervention and control groups using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 in each group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed a significant reduction in biomarkers (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention group and 1% in the control group.

Funding.evidence: The study was funded by institutional grants.
